quote: No. No. It's not fair.       Am I alone here? Is that it? Am   I the only one who sees.       What is that noise!
Why? Am I talking too fast?    Having trouble keeping up, Doctor?
I just don't want you to get    upset.
Please don't leave us here, Karen.    Please.
It's only for a few weeks,    Patrick.
You know what they're going to do    to us, don't you? You know why    they carted us halfway across the    quadrant? They're going to    experiment on us.
Stop it, Jack.
They want to find out what makes    our "genetically engineered"    brains tick. They're going to cut    our heads open and see what comes    out!
He's just trying to scare you,    don't listen to him. I told you    why I brought you here, remember?    To meet that Doctor? Doctor    Bashir?
You know. The handsome one.
He was genetically enhanced when    he was a boy, just like all of you.

No. No. He's not like us. I    never saw him at the Institute.    He wasn't locked away for being    too smart. He passed himself off    as normal. He's mister normal    Starfleet man. Mister productive    member of society. Maybe we can    learn to be just like him. Wear    a little uniform.        Yes, sir.        No, sir.        Thank you, sir.
I don't like it here.
It's going to be all right.    Doctor Bashir is going to work    with you for a while, that's all.    Think of it as a little vacation    from the Institute.
No. No. This isn't happening.
It is happening, Jack, and you're    going to have to try to make the    best of it.
I'm going to make the best of it.
See the way he's looking at me?    He's in love with me already.
Give me that.
I want to go home.
It's him.
See that? That's what I'm going    to do to your boyfriend.
Give me the PADD.
Sorry.
You're not sorry, Jack. We both    know that. You did it on purpose    because you're upset. But there    are better ways of dealing with    being upset.
I'll work on it.
All right, I'll see you all in a    few weeks.
Bye, Sarina.
Are you all right?
It's nothing. Just another run-in    with Jack. Like I said in my    report, don't turn your back on    him.
We'd better get you down to the    Infirmary.
I'll be fine. You go on in.    They're about as ready to meet you    as they'll ever be.         I just hope you have better luck    getting through to them than I've    had.
Hello?
Funny. He doesn't look like a    mutant.
Is that you, Jack?
He knows me. He knows my name.   I didn't tell him my name.
It's all right. I read Doctor    Loews's reports, that's all.
I knew that.
Hello, Sarina.
Why's he trying to talk to her?    He read the reports.        She won't answer. Didn't you read    the reports?
Would anyone mind if I turned on    some lights?
Would anyone mind if he turned on    some lights?        Go ahead. We're not mole people,    you know.
Computer, lights.
Hello.
Lauren.
I know what you're thinking,    Julian. But I'm not that kind of    girl.
Bashir, was it? Rings a bell.    Bashir, Bashir, Bashir. Got it!    Singh el Bashir, fifteenth century    poet. Any relation?
Yes, actually.
His work was totally derivative.    He was a plagiarist. You knew    that -- you had to know. But you    came in here bragging about it    anyway. Why?
You're the one who brought it up.
What was I supposed to do -- let   you get away with it?        That noise!
Tell me, Doctor...        What sort of... enhancements did    your parents have done to you?
Mental abilities, mostly. But    they had my hand-eye coordination,    reflexes and vision improved as    well.
Can you do that?
I doubt it.
What happened? Your parents    couldn't afford the full overhaul?
He turned out all right.
(giving her a withering     look)    You're not exactly known for being    discriminating.
I turned you down, didn't I?
And you're still regretting it.    (quick, as if to catch     Bashir off guard)    The cube root of three hundred    twenty-nine -- what is it?
Six point nine zero three.
Very good. You didn't even use    your fingers.        He's a mutant, just like the rest    of us.
No. He's not like us. No. He    passed as normal.
Is it true? You passed as normal?    Is it true?
My genetic status wasn't    discovered until last year.
How'd you manage to hide it for so    long?
I did my best not to... exploit my    abilities.

So no one would suspect. Very    clever. I'm impressed.        That's not right. There are    reasons why DNA resequencing is    illegal. There are reasons why    people like us are barred from    serving in Starfleet. We have an    advantage. Normal people can't    compete. It's not fair.
Maybe you're right... maybe I    should've said something sooner.
There are rules. Don't talk with    your mouth full. Don't open an    airlock when someone's inside.    Don't lie about your genetic    status. But you did. You lied.
And when you got caught, you cut    a deal with Starfleet and got    yourself off the hook.
If you'd told the truth, you    could've come and lived with us.    At the Institute.
He's right, you know. They    would've put you away.
They don't "put people away" for    being genetically engineered.
No, they just won't let us do    anything that's worth doing --    they're afraid we're going to take    over.
It happened before. People like    us did try to take over.
I knew it! I knew you were going    to trot out the Eugenics Wars.
I'm not trotting anything out.    All I'm saying is that there's a    reason we're barred from certain    professions. That doesn't mean we    can't be productive members of    society.

Here it comes. The "we have    something to contribute" speech.         No. No. I will not forget what    was done to me. I will not be    part of the society that locked me    away for being too smart. No.
All right, then. Since you seem    to have all the answers, I'll    spare you the speech.
Where are you going?
I'm having dinner with some    friends.
You think we don't eat? We eat.    We're going to eat right now. Yum-   yum.
I'll set the table.
Don't worry about us, we'll be    fine.
Thanks for chasing him off.
All I kept thinking was "there but    for the grace of God go I."
How do you mean?
My parents found a decent doctor    to perform the DNA resequencing on    me. These four weren't so lucky.

They all suffered unintended side-   effects. By the time they were    five or six years old, their    parents had to come forward and    admit that they'd broken the law    so their children could get    treatment.
Sounds like they waited too long.
There wasn't much the doctors at    the Institute could do for them --    cases like theirs are so rare    there's no standard treatment.
I can't imagine it was a very    challenging environment for them.
That's exactly what Doctor Loews    felt when she first came to the    Institute. She got permission to    separate them from the other    residents so she could work with    them.
Why did she bring them here?
She thought they might respond to    meeting someone who was like them,    but was living a normal life.    She's hoping that someday they'll    be able to live on their own and    be productive.
I hope they don't end up being too   productive -- it'd make the rest    of us look bad.
It is no laughing matter. If    people like them are allowed to    compete freely, parents would feel    pressured to have their children    enhanced so that they could keep    up.
That's precisely what prompted the    ban on DNA resequencing in the    first place.

Giving them a chance to contribute    doesn't mean sanctioning what was    done to them. They didn't ask to    have their DNA tampered with --    they were just children when it    happened. Why should they be    excluded when their parents are    the ones who broke the law?
You're right. It's not quite    fair. But even so it seemed a    good way to discourage genetic    tampering.
Besides, we're not talking about    excluding them, we're talking    about putting certain limits on    what they're allowed to do.
Like joining Starfleet.
Exactly.
Are you saying I shouldn't be    allowed to wear this uniform?
You... are an exception.
An exception. I suppose I should    be used to that, I've been one all    my life. First because of the    resequencing, and now because I'm    allowed to serve in Starfleet    anyway.
Perhaps I should not have said    anything.
It's all right.
Anyone care to speculate about    what Gul Damar is going to say in    his speech?
Nothing we're going to like, I'll    wager.
It should be starting any minute.
If he announces another new battle    offensive, it'll spoil dessert.
-- can you hear me? Hello?    Calling Doctor Bashir.
Jack?
Hello? Anybody there?
Did you give them access to the    com-system?
No, they must've broken in    somehow.
(continuing, excusing     himself)    I'd love to stay and chat about    our impending doom, but...
Do something about that noise!
What noise?
What kind of sick game are you   people playing?
What are you talking about?
Can't you hear it?
We complained and two very cute   Engineers came by and said there   was nothing wrong.
Wait a minute. Sort of a    high-pitched whine?
Yes. Thank god!
I told you we weren't crazy.
You are a mutant. You are.
Now do something about that noise    or I'll snap her neck.
I called Chief O'Brien... now let    her go.

quote: It was amazing. They pieced    together the entire story of how    Damar came to power. Don't you    see?

Weyoun is the Dark Knight, Gul    Dukat is the deposed King, Damar    is the Pretender to the throne,    and Ziyal is the innocent Princess    he murdered. Now the Pretender is    wracked with guilt over what he    did.
And they got all that just from    watching Damar's speech?
They were fascinated by the whole    thing, started bombarding me with    questions about Cardassia and the    war. I've never seen them so    engaged.
And you want to keep them engaged?
I'm going to try, but I'm running    out of material.
What do you mean?
They've already gone through    everything the computer has on    Cardassia and the Dominion.
Roll out the red carpet.
Visitors?
Starfleet has agreed to listen to    what Damar has to say. He and    Weyoun will be arriving in the    morning.        I'm the lucky one who gets to sit    across the table from them.
This is great.
It's hard to believe the Dominion    really wants peace. I wouldn't be    surprised if they were just    stalling for time in order to    regroup.
Sir, is there any way I can get a    transcript of the negotiations?
You can do better than that.        The Dominion insisted on recording    the proceedings so everyone can    see that their desire for peace is    sincere.
Perfect.
You shouldn't've agreed to that,    Benjamin.        Now you're going to have to be on    your best behavior.
So... the Pretender and his Dark    Knight are coming to the station.
The story's not over.
Peace Talks. Could be    interesting.
I'd say so. And the best part is,    we're going to have ringside    seats...
Ah, major...
Welcome to Deep Space Nine.
How nice to see you again.
Can I give you a word of advice,    Weyoun?
By all means.
You're welcome to play your little    "we're all friends here" act with    me. But I wouldn't try it on    Captain Sisko. He's not in the    mood.
We're on a mission of peace,    major. Maybe he should get in the    mood.
This is the border as it existed    before hostilities broke out.
This is the border we're now    proposing.
This arrangement would award    disputed star systems to the side    that already has effective control    over them. On the balance, we're    giving up more than you.

You can tell us.
They want the Kabrel System.
How do you know that?
They kept avoiding it with their    eyes.
You're sure, Patrick?
They kept avoiding it.
Told you they were up to    something.
End program.
All right... they want the Kabrel    System -- why?
I don't know, but they're willing    to give up a lot to get it. The    mizinite deposits on Holna Four    alone could keep their shipyards    running for years.
Yes, yes. That's a typical    Dominion strategy -- they offer to    give up something valuable to hide    the fact that they want something    even more valuable in the long    term.

That's how they think. The big    picture. They don't worry about    what's going to happen tomorrow --    pff -- they're thinking about    what's going to happen a year from    now, a decade, a century.
There must be something special    about the Kabrel System.
There's nothing on the first    planet but some simple protozoids    and tri-nucleic fungi. The second    planet has some cormaline deposits,    but that's common enough.
Okay, okay. Maybe there's another    reason -- does it have any    strategic value?

Chemistry was never my strong    suit.
What is it?

It shows how you can break down    tri-nucleic fungus to make yridium    bicantizine -- one of the active    ingredients in Ketracel White.    That's why the Dominion wants the    Kabrel System -- so they can    manufacture the drug here in the    Alpha Quadrant.
According to our calculations,    they'd be able to make enough    White to supply the Jem'Hadar    indefinitely.
I was going to recommend that the    Federation accept the proposed    border. It could've cost us the    Alpha Quadrant.
Actually, sir -- we should let    them have Kabrel.
And why's that?

If we don't, the Dominion will    have no choice but to launch a    full-scale attack before its    stockpile of White runs out.     (handing him another     PADD)   Here are the casualty projections.    As you can see, an attack would be    devastating for both sides.
You're suggesting we stall?
It'll buy us time to rebuild our    defenses. And it'll give us a    chance to bring the Romulans into    the alliance.
The Romulans?
According to our analysis, they'll    vote to abandon their    non-aggression pact with the    Dominion at next year's plenary    session.
By then, internal pressures within    the Cardassian-Dominion alliance    will have erupted.    (handing over still     another PADD)    Within three years, we're    projecting that --

Hang on a minute. How did you    come up with all this? Two days    ago you said these people were    impossible to deal with, now    they're turning out projections    that would take Starfleet    Intelligence months to come up    with.
We're mutants.
I know we're not exactly qualified    for this kind of work -- it might    even be beyond the "limits" of    what people like us should be    allowed to do --
But if you let me walk you through    the analyses, I think you'll be    impressed.
All right, doctor. Go ahead.
Thank you, sir.        The way the statistical model    we're using works, the farther    into the future we go, the more    accurate the projection.
Un-huh...
It has to do with non-linear    dynamics. Small-scale    fluctuations tend to factor out    over time. The net result is that --
Doctor, why don't you go back to    the beginning and take me through    it step by step, nice and easy.
Gladly, sir.
The captain said he was going to    take our analyses to Starfleet    Command right away.
Imagine that, Starfleet Command.
All those admirals.
It's a party!
It is now --
We need music.
Computer, music -- something    grand.
A waltz.
Care to dance?
Coward...
He tried.
I meant her.
Chief, what a nice surprise.
I need to replace that coupling.
Don't mind us.
Hi.
No, thanks.
It's a party.
I better get to work.
I didn't mean to... it's just   that...

Nothing.
Patrick, what is it?
He doesn't like me.
Sure I do.
See?
He doesn't like any of us.
(what am I supposed to     do?)   Julian --
He's jealous you're spending so    much time with us.
His wife's away, he misses his    friend.
I do not.
Go play with him, Julian, we'll be    fine.
Do you want me to play with you,    Miles?
No.
Yes, you do --
Come on. Let's go to Quark's.
I need those --
No, you don't. There's nothing    wrong with the power coupling.
Well... it's going to have to be    replaced sooner or later...
Ready?
Ready.
Sorry about that. The last thing    I meant to do was upset anyone.

scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: They are a bit candid, aren't    they?
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I'll say.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: The funny thing is, I'm actually    starting to enjoy their company.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Un-uh. Back here.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: You know what I've been thinking?    Starfleet Command would do all    right by taking them on as an    advisory team.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I don't know. It's a little hard    to picture them in a room with a    bunch of admirals.        -- unless they're going to teach    them how to dance.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: We were celebrating.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Whatever.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: They're really quite brilliant.    When we actually got down to    working, it was incredible. We    were all on the same wavelength,    talking in shorthand, finishing    each other's sentences -- I've    never had that with anyone else.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: After being around them, I can see    how the rest of us might seem kind    of... uncomplicated.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I wouldn't say that, exactly.    More like... slow.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Must be frustrating for you.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I don't mind. It makes me feel    superior.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Glad to be of service.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I appreciate it.        But even so, it's not always easy    to walk amongst the common people.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: It's probably best to keep your    expectations low.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: That way we can surprise you now    and then.        Another game?
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Sure. But do I have to stand so    far back?
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I make one lucky throw and you're    ready to come down to my level?
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I like to win as much as the next    man.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: Get back there.
scene: 27F  INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE ON THE DART BOARD

quote: I've got good news. Starfleet    Command was so impressed with our    analyses, they've agreed to let us    have access to classified    information on Starfleet's battle    readiness.
Is something wrong?
We did a long-term projection.   You'd better take a look.
You're not going to like it...
Well?
Everything checks out.
I was hoping you were going to    find a flaw.
No.
Then you agree with our    conclusion?
It's inescapable.    (wishing it weren't    true)   There's no way the Federation is   going to be able beat the   Dominion. We have no choice... we   have to surrender.
Surrender to the Dominion -- not    on my watch.

I understand how you feel, sir.    I don't like it any more than you    do. But it's the best option. We    ran dozens of different scenarios.    Even if something unlikely were to    happen that tilted the scales in    our favor -- say an anti-Dominion    coup on Cardassia -- we'd still    lose this war.
That doesn't mean we should just    give up and roll over.

If we fight, we'll take over nine    hundred billion casualties. If we    surrender, no one dies. Either    way we're in for five generations    of Dominion rule.        Eventually a rebellion will form,    centered on Earth. It'll start to    spread, and within another    generation, it'll succeed in    overthrowing the Dominion. The    Alpha Quadrant will unite in a    new, stronger Federation that'll    last thousands of years.        Since we can't win, why not    surrender and save as many lives    as we can?
Sir, I realize this isn't easy to    accept.
I don't accept it. Your entire    argument is based on a series of    statistical probabilities and    assumptions.
They're more than just    assumptions. If you want me to    take you through the equations, I    will.
Even if I knew what was going to    happen with one hundred percent    certainty, I still wouldn't ask an    entire generation of people to    give up their freedom.
Not even to save nine hundred    billion lives?
Surrender is not an option. I'm    happy to hear your group's advice    on how to win this war... I don't    need advice on how to lose it.
But there's no way we can win,    sir.

I don't care if the odds are    against us. If we lose, we're    going to go down fighting -- that    way, when our descendents rise up    against the Dominion someday,    they'll know what they're made of.
With all due respect, sir, you're    letting your pride get in the way.
All right, doctor. You've made    your recommendation. I'll pass it    on to Starfleet Command.
Sir, if you don't add your voice   to this, they'll reject it out of   hand.
I'm counting on it.
So we go down fighting...       How terribly courageous of us.
Well?
Pretty grim.
It's not grim, it's hopeless.    (quiet, so no one can     hear)   We can't beat them, Miles.
Doesn't look like it, does it?
We have to avoid a long and drawn    out war.
You mean surrender?
I know it's an ugly word, but    facts are facts.
I don't know, Julian.
Don't tell me you agree with the    captain.
I suppose I do.
Is there some part of the analysis    you didn't understand, because I'd    be happy to explain it.
I understood it perfectly.       Believe it or not.
That's not what I meant. All I'm    saying is that you have to look at    the bigger picture.
I'm trying. Maybe I'm just too    "uncomplicated" to see it.
I didn't say that.
You don't have to. You're acting    like no one with half a brain    could possibly disagree with you.
Frankly I don't understand how you    can.
The way I see it there are two    possible explanations. Either I'm    more feebleminded than you ever    realized, or you're not as smart    as you think you are.
Dabo!
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Looks like your lucky day.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Please. You and I both know these    so-called games of chance are no    such thing -- the odds are in the    house's favor.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Shh. Don't say that.    (looking at the other     players)    People are trying to have fun.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Sooner or later, no matter how    perfectly I play, no matter how    well I hedge my bets, I'm going to    lose.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Why are you trying to spoil    everyone's good time? Look    around, these people are enjoying    themselves. Half of them know the    odds are against them, but they    don't care. They're here because    they believe they can win. Is    that so bad?
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: They're fools.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: (reaching to remove     Bashir's bet)    Why don't you just take your    winnings and call it a day?
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Because I'm trying to prove a    point. There's no way to win.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Stop saying that.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: There. You see? We're all as    good as dead.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: Take it easy, Doctor, it's just a    game.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: You're right. It's not as if    billions of lives are at stake.
scene: 33   INT. QUARK'S - CLOSE - THE DABO WHEEL

quote: I just got word. Starfleet has    rejected our recommendation.
I knew it.
It's kind of a relief, in a way.    I mean, who wants to wave a white    flag?
They're the cowards! They don't    have the courage to see the truth.
You may be right. But there's    nothing we can do.
No. We can't just take this lying    down. There's too much at stake.        We've got to take matters into our    own hands.
How, Jack? What can we do?
We can't force Starfleet to    surrender.
(coming to a    realization)   If we can't head off the war,   there might be a way to make it a   lot less bloody.
How?
Look at this -- Starfleet battle    plans, fleet deployments -- do you    know what the Dominion could do    with this information?
They could take the Alpha Quadrant    in a matter of weeks.
With a lot fewer Federation    casualties than in a drawn out    war.
There wouldn't be more than --        -- two billion fatalities.
That's a lot better than nine    hundred billion.

Wait a minute. It was one thing   for us to try and avert a war,   it's another to take it upon   ourselves to trigger an invasion   that's going to get a lot of   people killed. It's not our place   to decide who lives and who dies.   We're not gods.
Maybe not, but we're the next best   thing.
Do you hear yourself? That's   exactly the kind of thinking that   makes people afraid of us.
I don't care! I'm willing to make   this decision.
It's not ours to make. We   presented our position to   Starfleet Command and they   rejected it. Case closed.
It's not closed! We're going   through with this.
I won't be party to treason.
Call it what you want. I'm   willing to do it if it means   saving billions of lives.
So... are you with us or not?
No. Haven't you been listening?
Fine.
How do we contact the Dominion?
I've been looking over Sisko's    latest counterproposal. We don't    seem to be getting anywhere with    him.
Not very encouraging, is it?
I don't know why you had me call    for peace talks in the first    place.
My, my -- how quickly you've taken    to your new role. And to think,    only a short time ago you were    nothing more than Gul Dukat's    adjutant.
I appreciate the faith you've    shown in me.
Then show a little faith in me.    Don't be like your predecessor,    second-guessing my every move. It    should be clear to you by now that    no one is irreplaceable.
Now... I just received a very    interesting message from an    unidentified party claiming to    have some information that could    be very beneficial to us.
What sort of information?
I don't know... but we're going to    find out...
Computer.       Computer, respond.
Sarina, where is everyone?
Did they arrange a meeting with   the Dominion?
Listen to me. We have to stop   them before it's too late.
Untie me. Please.       Sarina.
I'm sorry.
I can't untie you.
Yes, you can. If you think it's    the right thing to do.
I don't know...

I think you do. I think that's    why you spoke to me just now. You    could've stayed quiet, but you    didn't. And the only reason I can    think of is that you don't want to    have the deaths of so many people    on your hands.
Jack would be mad.
Yes, he would. And I know you    don't want that to happen.
I've seen the way you look at him    when you think no one is watching.    I know how much you care about    him.

Sarina, if you don't let me stop    them, they're going to be arrested    and charged with treason. Do you    know what that means? You'll    never see any of them again.         You'll never see Jack again.
Where are they?
They'll be here.
This is ridiculous. Sneaking into    a storage bay for a secret meeting --   I'm not some agent in the Obsidian    Order, I'm the leader of the    Cardassian Empire.
Don't let it go to your head. You    serve at the Dominion's pleasure.
Besides, I think it's exciting.
They're here.
Odo.
Yes, I know -- I "honor you" with    my presence.
We seem to have gotten ourselves    lost.
Mm-hm.       They're not coming.
Who's not coming?
I had a feeling you were going to    say that.        Shall I escort you to your    quarters?
Captain Sisko has decided not to    press charges. You're not going    to prison.
What are they going to do to us?
Nothing bad. You'll be sent back    to the Institute. Together.
It doesn't matter what happens to    us. Don't you realize what you've    done?
I kept you from committing    treason.
Are we supposed to thank you?    Nine hundred billion people are    going to die.
We don't know that.
Didn't you sit here and go through    the projections with us? Didn't    you?
He was here, Jack. I remember.
Maybe our projections were wrong.
How can you say that? We factored    in every variable, every    contingency -- the equations don't    lie!        You. You ruined everything.
What do you make of that, Jack?    Why didn't you anticipate it --    why didn't you factor her into    your equations?
You thought you knew everything,    but you didn't even know what was    going to happen in this room.

One person derailed your plans.    One person changed the course of    history.        I don't know about you, but that    gives me hope. It makes me think    that maybe, just maybe, things    don't have to turn out the way we    thought.
I heard what happened.
It was a pretty close call.
Luckily Odo managed to intercept    them in time.
That's not what I meant.

I'm talking about when you had to    decide whether or not to meet with    the Dominion. I'm sure it wasn't    easy -- I know you wanted to try    to save as many lives as possible.         It's probably what makes you such    a good doctor.
Fortunately this doctor's also a    Starfleet Officer.

We thought we were so smart. We    actually believed we could predict    the future.         It's my fault, not theirs. I    should never have let things go so    far. I guess I was just too bent    on proving to the world that they    have something to contribute.

They did contribute, Julian.         Seems to me we were starting to    get a little too complacent about    the Dominion. We may have driven    them back into Cardassian space,    but that doesn't mean we've beaten    them.
I only hope we can...
The odds may not be good, but all    we can do is take our best shot.
You're not going to cause any    more trouble, are you?
Not this time.
I'll double down.
Risky...
Maybe there's a better bet, but    when the odds are stacked against    you, sometimes you just have to    take a chance.
(confident of the     house's odds)    I admire your courage...
Dabo!
Well, what do you know... we have    a winner...
O'Brien to Bashir.
Go ahead.
You wanted to know when a certain    transport was leaving.
Thanks.
There's one problem, though.    We've got some passengers that are    refusing to board unless you come    see them.
I didn't think you'd want to see    me again.
Believe me, I wouldn't mind if our    projections turned out to be    wrong.
Jack's still furious, but I didn't    want to leave without saying    good-bye.
Will you come visit us?
I'd like that.
You did the right thing. Someday    he'll realize that.
Ready to go?
Not so fast. There's something I    need to know, doctor.
If we can come up with a way to    beat the Dominion, will you    listen?
I can't think of anything I'd like    better.
Good.        Let's go, let's go. We've got    work to do.
Bashir to O'Brien.       Four to beam out.
